abstractText: We give a linearized but otherwise complete supersymmetric action for N = (4, 0) supergravity in six dimensions, using a Kaluza-Klein-type 5 + 1 split of coordinates and fields. We provide in particular a significantly simplified version of the bosonic action derived by us recently. This formulation employs fields that are no longer irreducible, subject to a local Lorentz invariance, which in turn simplifies the supersymmetry transformations including the exotic gravitino.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Maximally supersymmetric theories play a unique role within string and M-theory, with their interactions being completely determined by supersymmetry. The unique 11-dimensional supergravity gives rise, upon dimensional reduction, to (ungauged) maximal supergravity in lower dimensions, as does the inequivalent type IIB supergravity in ten dimensions. Remarkably, however, in six dimensions (6D) there is the possibility of entirely new maximal supergravity theories, with multiplets carrying (3, 1) and (4, 0) supersymmetry [1, 2, 11–14]. These multiplets do not feature a conventional graviton, but instead are based on exotic tensor fields, with mixed Young tableaux representations and , respectively, subject to (exotic) self-duality relations. It was conjectured by Hull that these theories are strong coupling limits of N = 8 theories in five dimensions [1], but it remains unknown whether such exotic theories actually exist at the interacting level. Recently, we constructed action principles for the free bosonic parts of the (3, 1) and (4, 0) theories [3]. Since the dynamics of the exotic tensor fields is encoded in self-duality
– 1 –
J H E P 0 8 ( 2 0 2 2 ) 2 5 5
relations, it is not possible to write conventional manifestly Lorentz invariant actions. However, borrowing techniques from exceptional field theory [4, 5] one may write such actions upon performing a 5+1 split of the 6D coordinates (as in Kaluza-Klein theory, but without truncation), thereby abandoning manifest Lorentz invariance. These actions take the structural form of a 5D theory, but with the fields depending on all six coordinates and with explicit contributions from the derivative ∂5 along the sixth dimension. The resulting field equations are in fact equivalent to the 6D self-duality relations. Furthermore, these actions seem to be the ideal starting point in order to explore possible interactions, because in the limit ∂5 → 0 the interacting theory is immediate, being given by familiar 5D supergravity.1 A complete action for, say, (4, 0) supergravity could then potentially be constructed as a deformation in ∂5, and there is no longer a reason of principle why a consistently interacting theory should not exist.
In this paper we revisit our formulation for the free (4, 0) theory and complete it by introducing the fermionic fields, which includes exotic gravitini ψAµν (with USp(8) index A = 1, . . . , 8), and by constructing the complete supersymmetric action and the supersymmetry rules. To this end we give a significant simplification of the bosonic action derived in [3] by trading the fields that originally live in irreducible Young tableaux representations for reducible fields subject to a local Lorentz invariance. These reducible fields further absorb certain extra fields, which emerged due to the integration of two-derivative self-duality relations in the 5 + 1 split.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In section 2 we give the simplified formulation of the bosonic sector of the free (4, 0) theory. The complete supersymmetric action is then given in section 3. In section 4 we show that on-shell this action indeed implies the complete 6D supersymmetric (4, 0) theory at the free level, and we also give, for the first time, the explicit 6D supersymmetry rules. We close with a brief outlook, while an appendix collects various gamma matrix and spinor identities.

sections.heading: 2 Bosonic sector
sections.text: In this section we review (and improve) the action for the bosonic sector of (4, 0) supergravity in 6D. To this end we subject the self-duality equations in 6D to a 5 + 1 split of coordinates, without truncation, and integrate the result to an action with manifest 5D Lorentz invariance. We also provide a frame formulation with local Lorentz invariance, which in turn is convenient for the formulation of the supersymmetry rules provided in later sections.

sections.heading: 2.1 6D self-duality relations and 5 + 1 split
sections.text:
The N = (4, 0) multiplet in 6D contains 42 scalar fields, 27 self-dual two-forms, and a self-dual four-index tensor. We begin with the self-dual two-forms Bµ̂ν̂M , labelled by an

Hµ̂ν̂ρ̂ M = 16 εµ̂ν̂ρ̂σ̂κ̂λ̂H σ̂κ̂λ̂M . (2.1)
These equations cannot be obtained from a manifestly Lorentz invariant action in 6D, but an action can be provided upon performing a 5 + 1 split of coordinates (hence abandoning manifest Lorentz invariance). Specifically, we decompose the coordinates and indices as
{xµ̂} −→ {xµ, x5 = y} , µ = 0, 1, . . . , 4 , (2.2)
and similarly the 6D tensor fields as
{Bµ̂ν̂M} = {BµνM , Bµ5M ≡ AµM} . (2.3)
As shown in [3], the components of the self-duality equations (2.1) are then equivalently expressed by the duality equation
FµνM + 1 6εµνρστ H ρστ M = 0 , (2.4)
which in turn can be obtained by variation of the Lagrangian
LB = − 1 2 Fµν MFµνM − 112 ε µνρστ ∂5Bµν M Hρστ M , (2.5)
where HµνρM = 3 ∂[µBνρ]M , and we defined
FµνM ≡ FµνM + ∂5BµνM ≡ 2∂[µAν]M + ∂5BµνM . (2.6)
Note that this Lagrangian is invariant under gauge transformations of the structural form of a tensor hierarchy:
δAµ M = ∂µΛM − ∂5ΞµM , δBµνM = 2 ∂[µΞν]M + χµνM , (2.7)
where ∂5χµνM = 0. The χ gauge invariance follows from the fact that this shift in BµνM changes the Lagrangian only by a total ∂5 derivative. We next mimic this strategy for the exotic four-index tensor field contained in the N = (4, 0) multiplet. This field is denoted by Tµ̂ν̂,ρ̂σ̂ and carries the symmetries of the (2, 2) window Young tableaux (equivalently, the symmetries of the Riemann tensor):

Next we perform field redefinitions that simplify the structure of the theory. The above fields (hµν , Cµν,ρ, Tµν,ρσ) live in irreducible Young tableau representations, but it turns out to be beneficial to reorganize them into reducible representations, which in particular absorbs the newly introduced fields uµν , vρ,µν but also simplifies the gauge transformations.2 We begin with the four-index tensor Tµν,ρσ which we replace by

The field equations (2.23) show that after reduction to 5D (i.e. in the limit ∂5 → 0), the field Tµν,ρσ satisfies 3 ∂[µTνρ],στ = 0, such that it can be gauged to zero by the gauge transformations (2.26), which in this limit reduce to

In terms of these new field variables we can finally give the Lagrangian that reproduces the above integrated field equations and that is equivalent to the Lagrangian given in [3]. Specifically, for the fields (hµν , Ĉµν,ρ, Tµν,ρσ), which here and in the following we refer to as the spin-2 sector, the Lagrangian reads
L = −14 Ω̂ µνρΩ̂µνρ + 1 2 Ω̂ µνρΩ̂νρµ + Ω̂µΩ̂µ +

sections.heading: 2.3 Frame formulation
sections.text:
In this final subsection we give a further generalization of the above theory, which turns out to be beneficial, in particular for the presentation of the supersymmetry variations. We give a frame formulation with a local Lorentz invariance, for which the ‘metric fluctuations’

hµν receive an antisymmetric part, thereby rendering also this field reducible. Concretely, we postulate that the two fields (hµν , Ĉµν,ρ) are replaced by reducible fields (eµα, Cµνα) with gauge transformations
δeµ α = ∂µξα − ∂5Γµα − Λµα ,
δCµν,α = 2 ∂[µΓν]α + εµναβγ Λβγ + ∂5Λ[µν],α − 2 δα[µ∂5ξν] , (2.32)
where we introduced local Lorentz transformations with gauge parameter Λµν = −Λνµ. We should emphasize that the indices α, β, . . . are ordinary spacetime indices, on the same footing as µ, ν, . . . , but occasionally we shall chose such letters from the beginning of the greek alphabet in order to highlight their apparent role as frame indices of a putative non-linear theory of frame fields. The gauge transformations of Tµν,ρσ remain unchanged w.r.t. (2.26):
δTµν,ρσ = 2 ∂[µΛν],ρσ − ερσκλ[µ ∂5Λν]κλ − 4 ηρ[µ∂5Γν]σ + 4 ησ[µ∂5Γν]ρ − 4 εµνρστ ∂5ξτ . (2.33)
Let us first check that if we had a formulation with gauge symmetry (2.32) we could always fix a gauge so as to recover the gauge transformations in the form (2.26). There are two natural gauge conditions: first, we can pick the ‘symmetric’ gauge that the antisymmetric part of e vanishes, e[µν] = 0, in which case the spin-2 fluctuation of the previous subsection is recovered as hµν = 2eµν . In order not to undo the gauge fixing we have to add compensating gauge transformations:
δe[µν] = 0 ⇒ Λµν = ∂[µξν] − ∂5Γ[µν] . (2.34)
Upon identifying Cµνα = Ĉµνα this reproduces precisely the gauge transformation δĈµνα in the second line of (2.26). Second, we may pick the gauge condition that the totally antisymmetric part of Cµνα vanishes (thanks to the local Lorentz parameter acting according to the second term in δĈµνα in (2.26)). In this case, the compensating gauge transformations following from
0 = δC[µν,ρ] ⇒ Λαβ = 1 6 ε αβµνρ∂µΓνρ − 1 12 ε αβµνρ∂5Λµ,νρ , (2.35)
imply that we can identify
Cµν,ρ = Cµν,ρ , 2 eµν = hµν + 2uµν , (2.36)
as one may verify with (2.26). Let us finally write down the Lagrangian that permits to realize the enhanced gauge symmetry (2.32). We may start from (2.29) and promote the fields accordingly, but we have to allow for the possibility that terms need to be added that vanish in the above gauges. This is indeed what happens, and one finds the fully gauge invariant Lagrangian

3 N = (4, 0) supersymmetric Lagrangian in 5 + 1 split
In this section, we will start from the bosonic Lagrangian of N = (4, 0) supergravity built as a linear combination of (2.37) with (2.5) and the scalar Lagrangian and construct its fermionic extension as a maximally supersymmetric theory. Similar to the bosonic fields, the fermions in this formulation take the form of 5D fermions, however depending on all six space-time coordinates. In the supersymmetric model, all fields transform in representations of the 5D R-symmetry group USp(8). While the spin-2 sector is invariant under the R-symmetry, we relabel the 27 vector and tensor fields from (2.3) as{
Aµ AB, Bµν AB } , A,B = 1, . . . , 8 , (3.1)
by antisymmetric, symplectic traceless, index pairs [AB] of fundamental USp(8) indices, i.e.
Aµ AB = −AµBA , AµAB ΩAB = 0 , (3.2)
with the antisymmetric USp(8) invariant symplectic tensor ΩAB. Similarly, the 42 scalar fields of the free theory are most conveniently labelled by an antisymmetric traceless product of USp(8) indices as
φABCD = φJABCDK , i.e. φABCD = φ[ABCD] and φABCD ΩCD = 0 . (3.3)
The fermionic sector of the model contains the 8 gravitinos ψAµ in the fundamental representations of the 5D R-symmetry group USp(8), which we expect in maximal 5D

χABC = χJABCK , χABC ΩBC = 0 . (3.4)
We refer to [10] for our conventions of 5D USp(8) spinors. In particular, we have
γµνρστ = −iεµνρστ , ̄χ = χ̄ , ̄γµχ = χ̄γµ , ̄γµνχ = −χ̄γµν , (3.5)

Their presence can be inferred from the decomposition of the 6D exotic gravitino fields ΨAµ̂ν̂ , but also proves necessary for closure of the supersymmetry algebra in the 5 + 1 split. In some sense (to be made precise in (4.21)), they play the role of the superpartners of the exotic tensor field Tµν,ρσ. In particular, after reduction to 5D (i.e. in the limit ∂5 → 0), they have vanishing field strength ∂[µψνρ]A = 0, and can be set to zero by fermionic gauge transformations
δψAµν = 2 ∂[µκν]A , (3.6)

3.1 N = (4, 0) supersymmetry
Concretely, we impose the following supersymmetry transformation rules for the bosonic fields of the N = (4, 0) model

On dimensional grounds, the supersymmetry transformation of the bosonic fields is algebraic in the fermionic fields, in particular they remain unchanged in the ∂5 → 0 limit. The first four lines of (3.7) can thus be deduced from (linearized) maximal 5D supergravity [10] — except for the last term in δBABµν which in the reduction to 5D becomes a gauge transformation (3.6). The supersymmetry transformations of the exotic fields Cµνα and Tµναβ cannot be found in 5D supergravity and have to be derived by closure of the supersymmetry algebra.

• The first line of (3.12) is the linearized version of the bosonic sector of 5D maximal supergravity with the different objects ‘covariantized’ by ∂5 contributions accoding to (2.6) and (2.38). Similarly, the first two terms of the fifth line of (3.12) represent the linearized version of the fermionic sector of 5D maximal supergravity.
• Contrary to the bosonic fields BABµν , Cµνα, and Tµναβ which drop out of (3.12) in the limit ∂5 → 0, the exotic gravitino field ψAµν survives this limit with a non-trivial Rarita-Schwinger type kinetic term ψ̄µν Aγµνρστ∂ρψστA. However, its field equations in this limit imply its vanishing curvature ∂[µψνρ]A = 0, such that it can be set to zero by fermionic gauge transformations (3.6) as anticipated above.
• From the 5D perspective, the second line of (3.12) represents a number of topological Chern-Simons terms for two forms {Bµν , Cµν , Tµν}, with the antisymmetric metric given by 〈X,Y 〉 ∝ ∫ dy X∂5Y , together with index contraction over Lorentz and
USp(8) indices. The form of these terms may be read as a hint toward introducing interactions via putative non-linear gauge structures.
• Up to total derivatives, the Lagrangian (3.12) is also invariant under gauge transformations with fermionic gauge parameters

sections.heading: 4 Embedding into 6D
sections.text:
In the last section, we have constructed the N = (4, 0) supersymmetric extension of the bosonic Lagrangian of the model in the 5+1 split of coordinates, with all couplings uniquely determined by closure of the supersymmetry algebra. In this section, we will show that

To this end, we first work out the 6D supersymmetry transformation rules, decompose them according to the 5 + 1 coordinate split and modify them by on-shell vanishing contributions and fermionic gauge transformations in order to establish the equivalence with our previous results. Appendix A summarizes our 6D spinor conventions.

In this section, we also decompose the 6D supersymmetry transformations (4.5) according to the 5 + 1 split and match the resulting structures to the transformation laws presented in section 3.1 above. sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text:
In this paper we have given the complete free action for (4, 0) supergravity in 6D, using a 5 + 1 split of coordinates. This includes the fermionic fields such as exotic gravitini, as well as the supersymmetry rules. Due to the 5 + 1 split, the 6D Lorentz invariance is not manifest, but the theory is fully equivalent to (4, 0) supergravity at the free level, as follows by integrating the equations of motion following from this action. For the special case that the sixth coordinate parameterizes a circle, this action encodes the dynamics of all Kaluza-Klein modes that in turn organize into BPS multiplets of the supersymmetry algebra [19].
This work suggests various generalizations. First, in [3] we gathered evidence that there is a master formulation that universally encodes the conventional 6D, N = (2, 2) supergravity together with the exotic (3, 1) and (4, 0) theories. Specifically, this master formulation extends exceptional field theory, in which fields transform covariantly under E6(6) and depend on 5 + 27 coordinates, subject to a covariant section constraint [4, 5]. As suggested by the structure of the BPS multiplets, this generalization adds a singlet coordinate and extends the section constraint whose solutions then correspond to the (2, 2), (3, 1) or (4, 0) theory. This master formulation is, however, not yet complete for the spin-2 sector, where the analysis of [3] implied additional mass terms for the 5D graviton hµν that were not visible in the (4, 0) theory. Remarkably, in terms of the redefined field variables including Tµν,ρσ precisely such terms emerge in (2.29), suggesting that this form is much closer to the complete master formulation. The main challenge is to find a formulation including Tµν,ρσ together with a mechanism that renders this field pure gauge for the (3, 1) theory which does not feature this field.
Most importantly, it remains to actually define the fully interacting version of any of the exotic theories. We believe that the formulation presented here is particularly promising for attempting to write such a non-linear theory in terms of frame-like field variables. The frame formulation of section 2.3 suggests to take the fundamental bosonic fields of the spin2 sector to be differential forms with external Lorentz indices, namely: a one-form frame field Ea = Eµadxµ and two-forms Ca(2) = 1 2Cµν adxµ ∧ dxν and T ab(2) = 1 2Tµν
abdxµ ∧ dxν . For instance, the topological terms in the action for T ab(2) then take the natural ChernSimons form
LCS = − 1 16∂5T(2) ab ∧ dT(2)ab + · · · , (5.1)
up to non-linear terms that make the equations of motion compatible with dT(2)ab = ∂5J(3)ab, with the Lorentz-valued ‘3-form current’ suggested by the expression (2.24):
J(3)ab = 1 2 εabcde ( Ec ∧ T de(2) − 2 3E c ∧ Ed ∧ Ee ) + 4E[a ∧ C(2)b] . (5.2)
Indeed, expanding as Eµa = δµa + eµa to first order this precisely reproduces the current Jµνρ,αβ used in the main text. Similarly, all other terms in the action and symmetry transformations allow for a natural writing in terms of differential forms, which in turn suggests at least part of the non-linearities that the interacting theory must possess. It
– 17 –
J H E P 0 8 ( 2 0 2 2 ) 2 5 5
remains to define the complete non-linear gauge structure and interactions compatible with maximal supersymmetry.
